page.title: 14Historic Buildings
page.content: Wolvey was known as 'Ulveia' in the Domesday Book of 1086.The{CHURCH}of St John the Baptist, originally Norman, is a building of Attleboro' sandstone chiefly in the decorated style. It has a tower of the late 15th century containing six bells. Wolvey Hall reputedly built in 1676 in place of an earlier mansion destroyed during the{CIVIL WAR}is the property of Mrs Burbage who is a member of the{ {COAPE-ARNOLD}family. At the Norman Conquest, Wolvey was granted to Robert de Vesci, who held here a manor comprising the village and a church. It later became the property of the Newburghs, Earls of Warwick, who sold it to the Bassetts and from them the{HALL}and manor passed, circa 1250, to the de Wolveys, with whose descendents it remained until 1780.
